channel.title: The Sydney Morning Herald National Headlines
channel.description: The top National headlines from The Sydney Morning Herald. For all the news, visit http://www.smh.com.au.

item.title: Egypt drops charges against Aust journo
item.description: Foreign Minister Bob Carr says Egypt has dropped proceedings against an Australian journalist accused of inciting public unrest.

item.title: Let's dance
item.description: Cate Sayers gets children with Down syndrome up on their feet and dancing - and transforms their lives.

item.title: Banknote chiefs defend dining, golf
item.description: Junkets 'part of the culture' of doing business in Asia, Melbourne Magistrates Court hears.

item.title: Alcohol abuse estimates attacked
item.description: THE alcohol industry is responding to stricter controls on drinking by using a New Zealand economist to challenge estimates that abuse is costing the nation $15 billion a year.

item.title: New policies yet to stem the boats
item.description: Chris Bowen concedes offshore processing policy not yet deterring illegal boats.

item.title: Security scheme worthy of 'police state'
item.description: Privacy Commissioner slams laws that would allow Australians' data to be stored for two years.

item.title: What a man wants: more flexible work schedules
item.description: CHRIS MARRABLE quit his last job because his employer would not give him the flexibility he needed to collect his 10-year-old son, Khyle, from school.

item.title: Are you sitting comfortably? Doctors find high risk of injury and illness in office
item.description: WORKERS who compensate for spending hours in front of a computer by using ergonomic chairs, standing desks and good posture are still likely to suffer back, neck, wrist and shoulder injuries, while also increasing their risk of heart disease, obesity and diabetes, doctors say.

item.title: Carbon changes will hit budget surplus
item.description: AUSTRALIA'S carbon price will be set by the volatile European market from 2015 under changes announced by the Gillard government that could hit the budget bottom line and cut incentives for switching to green energy.

item.title: Ford hints end nigh for its car making
item.description: FORD has given the strongest hint yet it's considering a life in Australia without manufacturing. In a frank admission, the president of Ford Australia, Bob Graziano, said manufacturing was no longer critical to the Australian operation's survival.

item.title: Grocon boss slams IR regime as dispute turns nasty
item.description: GROCON boss Daniel Grollo has attacked Australia's industrial relations regime, saying he is losing hundreds of thousands of dollars a day from a near week-long picket line and bitter dispute in Melbourne's CBD.

item.title: Internet data tracking proposal seen as 'a police state'
item.description: PROPOSED laws that would allow the web and telecommunications data of all Australians to be stored for two years have been dubbed ''characteristic of a police state''.

item.title: Questions raised over super trawler's quota
item.description: THE federal Environment Minister, Tony Burke, is seeking urgent advice about whether he can try to stop the super trawler MV Margiris fishing off the Australian coast.

item.title: Revealed: dole recipients too poor to buy food, medication or heating
item.description: SHOCKING findings from research commissioned by the government show that one in 10 Australians on the dole are unable to obtain a substantial meal each day, one in eight are unable to buy prescribed medicines, and one in 20 cannot heat their homes.

item.title: Warne off after bowling his maiden over
item.description: IF THE celebrity media mill is to be believed, the Shane Warne and Liz Hurley travelling sideshow could soon be leaving Australia, bound for Britain and a new $9 million love nest.

item.title: Patel says he did his best for patients
item.description: THE former Bundaberg surgeon Jayant Patel has proclaimed his faith in the Australian legal system in his first public comments since being charged seven years ago.

item.title: PM's concession on carbon
item.description: Government tweaks its carbon price, endangering incentives for the switch to cleaner energy.

item.title: Carr calls for inquiry into rebel's death
item.description: AUSTRALIA has made calls at the highest level for the Indonesian government to open an inquiry into the death of a West Papuan separatist leader in June.

item.title: Vic building watchdog accuses unions
item.description: Victoria's construction unions are infiltrated by organised crime, more than anywhere else in Australia, watchdog claims.

item.title: Industry attacks alcohol abuse research
item.description: In the face of calls for measures to counter grog abuse, the alcohol industry is financing an academic critique of 'nanny state' measures, importing a New Zealand economist who challenges a $15 billion estimate of the annual cost of alcohol abuse in Australia.

item.title: Full transcript: Cate Sayers
item.description: Cate Sayers speaks to Michael Short in The Zone

item.title: PM warns public servants of coalition cuts
item.description: Prime Minister Julia Gillard has warned public servants of another mass shedding of staff if the coalition wins government.

item.title: Another shark attack in WA waters
item.description: A person believed to be a male surfer has suffered injuries in a shark attack off WA, but has been rescued and is conscious.

item.title: Bundaberg surgeon Patel speaks out
item.description: Former Bundaberg surgeon Jayant Patel has offered his "deepest sorrow and sympathy" to everyone affected by his trial and subsequent appeals.

item.title: Bunny Luke's NRL return in the air
item.description: There is doubt over Issac Luke's return to the NRL for South Sydney with the star hooker named on an extended bench for the match with Newcastle.

item.title: Wallaby Mitchell faces lengthy layoff
item.description: Hapless Wallabies winger Drew Mitchell isn't sure if he will play again in the next 12 months after rupturing an ankle tendon last weekend.

item.title: Titans not worthy of finals: coach
item.description: The Gold Coast may yet pull off an NRL finals "miracle" but Titans coach John Cartwright has hinted that his side may not be top eight worthy.

item.title: Minmetals says Chinese investment okay
item.description: The head of Minmetals Resources says Australians had no reason to worry about Chinese companies investing in Australia.

item.title: Sam Williams named for Raiders
item.description: Playmaker Sam Williams has been named to play for Canberra against the Warriors despite suffering a shoulder injury last weekend.

item.title: AFL No.2 considers big rugby league offer
item.description: AFL chief operating officer Gillon McLachlan is one of the frontrunners to become the permanent NRL chief executive.

item.title: Toovey plays down top four for Manly
item.description: Manly coach Geoff Toovey has played down the importance of a top-four finish despite history suggesting you need it to reach the grand final.

item.title: Segeyaro return for NQ may be in vain
item.description: Cowboys hooker James Segeyaro has pulled off a remarkable comeback from injury to be named in an extended North Queensland side - but it may be for nought.

item.title: Docker Grover announces AFL retirement
item.description: After 14 seasons at the elite level, Fremantle defender Antoni Grover says the time is right for him to call it quits.

item.title: Oppn, Labor clash over govt spending cuts
item.description: Labor and the federal opposition have clashed over the depth of public service cuts in the states and what action an Abbott government would take.

item.title: Sharks NRL future looking rosy
item.description: Cronulla's financial future looks bright after the NSW government approved a $300 million redevelopment of land around the Sharks Leagues Club.

item.title: Budget surplus still on track, says Swan
item.description: Treasurer Wayne Swan admits commodity prices have fallen more than the government was expecting, but says a surplus will still be delivered in 2012/13.

item.title: Grant ready for clash with Civoniceva
item.description: Penrith prop Tim Grant is looking forward to going up against former teammate Petero Civoniceva in Friday night's clash with Brisbane.

item.title: Foley signs 3-year AFL deal with Tigers
item.description: Richmond midfielder Nathan Foley has signed a three-year contract extension with the AFL club.

item.title: Think tank welcomes link to Europe ETS
item.description: The Climate Insitute has cautiously welcomed the government's plan to link Australia's carbon laws with those of the European Union.

item.title: Belcher eyes Rio with new sailing partner
item.description: Gold medal-winning sailor Mathew Belcher has golden hopes for the Rio Olympics and beyond with a new partner.

item.title: Carbon tax change shows flaws: Abbott
item.description: The government is patching up its carbon tax when it should be scrapping it, Opposition Leader Tony Abbott says

item.title: Australia to link with EU ETS in 2015
item.description: The Labor government will not implement a planned floor price of carbon that would have applied from 2015.

item.title: NBL games to be streamed on internet
item.description: Basketball Australia has signed a new broadcast deal, allowing fans to stream games live over the internet for the first time in the sport's history.

item.title: Head knocks taken seriously, say Dockers
item.description: Fremantle coach Ross Lyon says it's up to the club's medical staff to determine whether a player can return to the field after a head knock.

item.title: Dragons ready for tough NRL finale
item.description: St George Illawarra's Matt Cooper says a desire to send out retiring teammates as winners will ensure a tough NRL match against Parramatta on Sunday.

item.title: Asylum policy needs time to work: Bowen
item.description: The federal government says the new asylum seeker offshore processing policies need more time to work.

item.title: Grocon site blockade injunction extended
item.description: The Victorian Supreme Court has extended an injunction stopping a union blockade of the Melbourne construction site where clashes with police occurred.

item.title: I can get better: says Souths star Inglis
item.description: As amazing as it seems, South Sydney fullback Greg Inglis says his game has room for improvement.

item.title: Marshall cleared to play against Storm
item.description: Benji Marshall has pleaded guilty to a dangerous contact charge, freeing the Wests Tigers halfback to play against Melbourne in Staurday night's NRL clash.

item.title: GrainCorp to create mega oils business
item.description: GrainCorp has bought Goodman Fielder's oil business Integro and private oilseed crusher Gardner Smith.

item.title: Legal costs put Centro in the red
item.description: Costs related to its settlement of a class action have contributed to a $223 million loss for shopping centre owner Centro Retail Australia.

item.title: Shorten urges Grocon and union to talk
item.description: Federal Workplace Minister Bill Shorten is hopeful the industrial dispute between the CFMEU and Grocon can be resolved.

item.title: Eagle Lynch in hard AFL selection battle
item.description: Last week's return of ace spearhead Josh Kennedy means West Coast veteran Quinten Lynch is no longer a guaranteed selection.

item.title: Sydney Grocon workers to stop work
item.description: Construction workers will down tools in Sydney on Wednesday to discuss a clash between police and union members in Melbourne.

item.title: Lib premiers suffer from IR agenda: Swan
item.description: Liberal Party premiers are losing support due to the party's stance on industrial relations, health and education, Treasurer Wayne Swan says.

item.title: Budget-cut premiers doing good job: Abbott
item.description: Opposition Leader Tony Abbott says state premiers are doing the right thing by making tough cuts to public spending.

item.title: Dispute shuts Newcrest's Lihir mine
item.description: A dispute with land owners has caused a shutdown at Newcrest's Lihir mine in Papua New Guinea.

item.title: Swan slams Lib foreign investment policy
item.description: The Liberal Party's foreign investment policy is in shambles and damaging to our national interests, Treasurer Wayne Swan says.

item.title: Dulux delivers ultimatum to Alesco
item.description: DuluxGroup has threatened to walk away from takeover talks with Alesco Corporation if a resolution can't be reached on the details of its offer.

item.title: Sheedy to coach GWS at least one more year
item.description: Kevin Sheedy has signed a one-year contract extension to continue as coach of Greater Western Sydney.

item.title: Abbott to mirror Newman on job cuts: Swan
item.description: Treasurer Wayne Swan says Queensland government plans to cut public service jobs reveal the federal coalition's intentions.

item.title: Sydney to host G20 finance ministers
item.description: Treasurer Wayne Swan has announced that Sydney will host a G20 finance minister's meeting in 2014.

item.title: Fewer public servants to go in Qld: Newman
item.description: Premier Campbell Newman says fewer Queensland public servants will lose their jobs than initially expected, but is yet to say how many.

item.title: Wallaby Vickerman retires from rugby
item.description: Wallabies second rower Dan Vickerman has announced his retirement from all levels of rugby after playing 63 Tests for Australia.

item.title: Home sales weak again in July
item.description: An industry indicator has shown a return to weakness for new home sales in July after repeated months of strength.

item.title: Storm may rest NRL players for Tigers
item.description: Melbourne may consider resting some players in their final round NRL clash with the Wests Tigers as they prepare for the finals.

item.title: Two men sent to trial over cop murder
item.description: Two men, committed to stand trial over the murder of Gold Coast detective Damian Leeding, won't face court until the second half of 2013.

item.title: Ingall sounds V8 enduros warning
item.description: V8 Supercars veteran Russell Ingall says he doesn't fear any of the championship's top contenders going into this year's endurance events.

item.title: Seven Group profit more than doubles
item.description: Media and earthmoving machinery company Seven Group Holdings has more than doubled its full year profit to $166 million.

item.title: Virgin Australia back in the black
item.description: Virgin Australia says its growth in the corporate travel sector has contributed to strong profit growth in the year to June.

item.title: Nauru detention centre will be full
item.description: Nauru's temporary asylum seeker detention centre will be at full capacity as soon as it opens.

item.title: Flight Centre posts strong profit growth
item.description: Travel agent Flight Centre has increased its full year profit by 43 per cent to $200 million and forecast further growth in the year ahead.

item.title: Vic riot police battle building protesters
item.description: Violence has flared outside a central Melbourne building site, with construction union members battling police in riot gear and on horseback.

item.title: Jackson hits back in HSU power play
item.description: Health Services Union national secretary Kathy Jackson says moves to oust her for gross misconduct are a "total fabrication" and politically motivated.

item.title: Fifth asylum boat in two days arrives
item.description: Another asylum seeker boat, this one carrying 43 people, has been intercepted near the Cocos Islands.

item.title: NSW opposition backs tunnel air monitoring
item.description: Calls from health lobby groups for increased air pollution monitoring in Sydney's M5 tunnel have been backed by the NSW opposition.

item.title: Cast away: waiting game is over for anglers as rivers come alive with fish
item.description: FOR years they have stood on the banks of sluggish, tepid rivers sucked dry by drought with nary a nibble at the end of their line.

item.title: Murray-Darling rescue not out of the water yet, says frustrated minister
item.description: NSW has warned there are still major hurdles to be overcome before an agreement can be reached to save the ailing Murray-Darling river system, as the clock ticks down on finalising a deal this year.

item.title: Spectre of WorkChoices puts Abbott, Howard at odds
item.description: THE Opposition Leader, Tony Abbott, has distanced himself from the legacy of John Howard after the former prime minister put him under pressure over industrial relations, the economy, the GST and the carbon price.

item.title: Standoff at HSU as secretary told to go
item.description: THE acting national president of the embattled Health Services Union, Chris Brown, has moved formally to remove Kathy Jackson as the union's national secretary and is expecting a long and protracted fight.

item.title: Caltex wins as drivers switch to premium
item.description: MOTORIST concerns over ethanol blends have resulted in strong rises in the use of premium fuels - and a big increase in profits for Caltex, which last month announced it was closing its Kurnell refinery and shedding 330 jobs.

item.title: Prenatal autism test may deliver ethical questions
item.description: CAITLIN O'NEILL is a happy, gurgling baby, an adored third child to her parents and the centre of her brother Gabriel's world.

item.title: Paralympics leaps all hurdles from afterthought to elite competition
item.description: Swimmer Karni Liddell has seen the Paralympics come a long way from the 'shambles' of the 1996 Atlanta Games.

item.title: New Griffin boss wants the world as her stage
item.description: With one eye on home soil and another looking abroad, Lee Lewis is aiming to take Griffin Theatre Company and its Australian stories to fresh territory overseas, and not just English-speaking zones.

item.title: Australian voters would deliver Obama landslide victory
item.description: IF AUSTRALIANS could vote in the United States presidential election, they would choose Barack Obama over Mitt Romney by a margin of 14 to one, a poll shows.

item.title: Designer recreates the classics with his take on wearable art
item.description: A SYDNEY entrepreneur is drawing on priceless international artworks and is using them to start a local fashion label.

item.title: Move aside: Paralympians take over as main act
item.description: For some, the Olympics are the warm-up for the later contest, writes Louise Schwartzkoff.

item.title: Rising cost of asylum seekers poses threat to delivering surplus
item.description: THE cost to the budget of staffing immigration detention facilities has ballooned by almost $650 million due to the large influx of asylum seekers over the past year, putting more pressure on the government to meet its surplus promise.

item.title: US study finds benefits outweigh risks of circumcising baby boys
item.description: CIRCUMCISION of newborn boys, a procedure that has polarised Western medical opinion, has got the tick from the influential American Academy of Pediatrics.

item.title: Key files 'missing' in banknotes scandal
item.description: Eight former executives from Note Printing Australia and Securency are facing committal.

item.title: Ruling shifts stance on snip
item.description: The influential American Academy of Paediatrics has shifted its stance on circumcision.

item.title: Arctic encounter: how the ice man Neil Armstrong finally melted
item.description: IT WAS the ultimate man's man getaway. The first man to climb Everest; the first man to walk on the moon; the man who would later be the first to fly solo non-stop around the world in a balloon and another who would be first to climb the ''seven summits'' - the highest peaks on seven continents.

item.title: Make kids get phone licence, says expert
item.description: NSW schools should introduce a licence for students before they can use mobile phones and tablets at school, says the adolescent psychologist Michael Carr-Gregg.

item.title: Prolonged cannabis use leads to drop in IQ, study shows
item.description: AUSTRALIAN doctors and health researchers have called for an anti-tobacco smoking-style campaign on the dangers of cannabis after a study found a link between long-term use of the drug and a significant, and possibly irreversible, drop in intelligence.

item.title: HSU head moves to oust Jackson
item.description: The acting national president is taking steps to remove national secretary Kathy Jackson.

item.title: Website 'erosion' worries insiders
item.description: Victoria's Department of Sustainability and Environment to purge its website of key information.

item.title: O'Farrell dismisses Newspoll results
item.description: NSW Premier Barry O'Farrell has shrugged off poor opinion poll results, saying he's more interested in what he's doing for the state.

item.title: Aussie jails rife with drugs: report
item.description: The Australian National Council on Drugs says many of the nation's prisoners are using illicit drugs regularly despite crackdowns on supply.

item.title: Murray-Darling consensus is close: Burke
item.description: Federal Water Minister Tony Burke says the state and federal governments are closer than ever before to a consensus on the Murray-Darling Basin plan.

item.title: We've carried players in AFL, Ratten says
item.description: Carlton coach Brett Ratten says the team is gutted after the shock loss to Gold Coast, a result that ended their AFL finals hopes.
